abstract_summ: It is known that while it is possible to convert between many different representations of irrational numbers (e.g., between Dedekind cuts and Cauchy sequences), it is in general not possible to do so subrecursively: conversions in general need to perform unbounded search.The purpose of this paper is to prove the following positive result: for a number of well-known representations (Beatty sequences, Dedekind cuts, General base expansions, Hurwitz characteristics, and Locators) conversion between the representations can be performed effectively and with good subrecursive bounds.In this paper, we rerun the search for ovals in a projective plane of order ten and produce a collection of nonexistence certificates that, when taken together, imply that such ovals do not exist.The Parikh matrix mapping allows us to describe words using matrices.Furthermore, it is known that there are irrational numbers x such that the expansion of x in one integer base is efficiently computable, but the expansion of x in certain other integer bases is not.
title_summ: Reducing the Ambiguity of Parikh MatricesNonexistence Certificates for Ovals in a Projective Plane of Order TenLiouville Numbers and the Computational Complexity of Changing BasesOn the Complexity of Conversion Between Classic Real Number Representations
title_abstract_phrases: On the Complexity of Conversion Between Classic Real Number RepresentationsIt is known that while it is possible to convert between many different representations of irrational numbers (e.g., between Dedekind cuts and Cauchy sequences), it is in general not possible to do so subrecursively: conversions in general need to perform unbounded search.Reducing the Ambiguity of Parikh MatricesThe Parikh matrix mapping allows us to describe words using matrices.In this paper, we rerun the search for ovals in a projective plane of order ten and produce a collection of nonexistence certificates that, when taken together, imply that such ovals do not exist.The purpose of this paper is to prove the following positive result: for a number of well-known representations (Beatty sequences, Dedekind cuts, General base expansions, Hurwitz characteristics, and Locators) conversion between the representations can be performed effectively and with good subrecursive bounds.Furthermore, it is known that there are irrational numbers x such that the expansion of x in one integer base is efficiently computable, but the expansion of x in certain other integer bases is not.
